Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Control, Computing, and Signal Processing Challenges in Future Power Systems. To be Held in Arlington,VA in November, 2013

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transformative research activities in the last decade focused on sustainable, robust, and reliable power systems have presented several paradigms such as smart grids, self-healing grids, and distributed generation. This workshop seeks to address the Control, Computing, and Signal Processing Challenges in Future Power Systems within the context of developing the tools for a system-level understanding of the impact of these emerging paradigms. It will promote cross fertilization of ideas with the aim of developing the underlying foundational science to realize next-generation electric generation, transmission, and distribution systems.

Intellectual Merit:

The workshop will bring together prominent researchers in relevant disciplines to address key questions relevant to future power systems, including: 1) What emerging control paradigms will improve management of renewables and charging of electric vehicles, with build-in resilience against failures and malicious attacks on critical infrastructure? 2) What is the role of optimization, big data analytics, and grid informatics in revitalizing power delivery subsystems and improving consumer satisfaction? 3) How can advances in statistical signal processing and machine learning be leveraged to improve situational awareness and system reliability? 4) How can we educate next-generation engineers about system-level challenges in future power systems?

Broader Impacts:

This workshop will engage several engineering disciplines to map out the foundational science for research in future power systems. The workshop will also emphasize the related educational aspects, primarily by leveraging the long tradition of excellence in power and energy systems education that the University of Minnesota has established through the NSF-supported Consortium of Universities for Sustainable Power.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering breakthroughs that will fundamentally revitalize the electric infrastructure have produced several paradigms such as smart grids, self-healing grids, and distributed generation. This workshop focused on uncovering the systems-level science to understand the impact of emerging advanced communication, control, and computing infrastructure on sustainable, robust, and reliable future power systems. To this end, the workshop engaged several engineering disciplines to map out the foundational science for research in future power systems. While the central role of the power and energy systems community is undeniable, the nature and scope of this initiative is certainly multidisciplinary, necessitating the inclusion of the control systems, computer science, optimization, machine learning, and signal processing communities. 

The workshop included invited plenary talks and breakout panel discussions. These talks and panel discussions were organized in the following general thematic areas: i) Modeling, analysis, and control of power networks; ii) Optimization, signal processing, and grid informatics; iii) Computation and economics; and iv) Security and integration. In each of these areas, several key observations and findings were made. With regard to modeling, analysis, and control, it was recognized that scalable models need to be developed in line with the big data era. The control of distribution networks was recognized to be a key challenge, and relevant algorithmic advances for operations and control were outlined. Advances in optimization, signal processing, and grid informatics were noted to be tightly tied to advances in the big data arena, and driven by the expanded role of phasor measurement units and other smart-grid technologies. The role of improved economic models was recognized to improve market flexibility and to leverage computational advances in economic and market considerations. Finally, the workshop also dwelled on considerations that would improve situational awareness across the complex cyber-physical layers that constitute the power system, and stressed on the formulation of integrated and cohesive power system security policies.
